paragraph.content: delivers to another any thing which is, and which he knows or believes to be, such a counterfeit, intending that the person to whom it is delivered, or another, shall pass or tender it as genuine,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years.

subsection.content: A person who delivers to another, without lawful authority or excuse, any thing which is, and which he knows or believes to be, a counterfeit of a currency note or of a protected coin, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s100
section.heading: Offences involving the custody or control of counterfeit notes and coins

subsection.content: A person who has in his custody or under his control any thing which is, and which he knows or believes to be, a counterfeit of a currency note or of a protected coin, intending either to pass or tender it as genuine or to deliver it to another with the intention that he or another shall pass or tender it as genuine, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years.

A person who has in his custody or under his control, without lawful authority or excuse, any thing which is, and which he knows or believes to be, a counterfeit of a currency note or of a protected coin, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 3 years.

For the purposes of this section it is immaterial that a coin or note is not in a fit state to be passed or tendered or that the making or counterfeiting of a coin or note has not been finished or perfected.

section.name: s101
section.heading: Offences involving the making or custody or control of counterfeiting materials and implements

subsection.content: A person who makes, or has in his custody or under his control, any thing which he intends to use or permit any other person to use for the purpose of making a counterfeit of a currency note or of a protected coin with the intention that it be passed or tendered as genuine, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years.

A person who, without lawful authority or excuse, makes, or has in his custody or under his control, any thing which, to his knowledge, is or has been specially designed or adapted for the making of a counterfeit of a currency note, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), a person who makes, or has in his custody or under his control, any implement which, to his knowledge, is capable of imparting to any thing a resemblance to the whole or part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of either side of a protected coin; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of the reverse of the image on either side of a protected coin,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 3 years.

subsection.leadIn: It shall be a defence for a person charged under subsection (3) to show that he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: made the implement or, as the case may be, had it in his custody or under his control, with the consent in writing of the Monetary Authority; or (Amended 82 of 1992 s. 28)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: had some other lawful authority, or a lawful excuse, for making it or having it in his custody or under his control.

section.name: s102
section.heading: Criminal possession
section.content: Where under this Part it is an offence for any person to have in his custody or under his control anything which is, and which he knows or believes to be, a counterfeit of a currency note or of a protected coin, a person shall be deemed to have such thing in his custody or under his control, notwithstanding that it is not in his personal custody or possession, if he knowingly and wilfully has it in the actual custody or possession of some other person, or in any building, lodging, apartment, field or other place, whether open or enclosed, whether occupied by himself or not, and whether the instrument or thing is in such custody, possession or place for the use of such person or for the use or benefit of another person.

section.name: s103
section.heading: The offence of reproducing Hong Kong currency notes

subsection.content: A person who, without the consent in writing of the Monetary Authority, reproduces on any substance whatsoever, and whether or not to the correct scale, any Hong Kong currency note or any part of a Hong Kong currency note, commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to imprisonment for 6 months and a fine at level 4. (Amended 82 of 1992 s. 29; E.R. 4 of 2021)

subsection.def: In this section, Hong Kong currency note (香港流通紙幣) means a currency note of the kind described in paragraph (a) of the definition of currency note in section 96.

section.name: s104
section.heading: Offences of making, etc. imitation Hong Kong coins

subsection.leadIn: A person who, in connection with a scheme intended to promote the sale of any product or with the making of contracts for the supply of any service, and without the previous consent in writing of the Monetary Authority to the sale or distribution of imitation Hong Kong coins in connection with that scheme— (Amended 82 of 1992 s. 30)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes an imitation Hong Kong coin;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: sells or distributes any imitation Hong Kong coin; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has in his custody or under his control any imitation Hong Kong coin with a view to selling or distributing it,

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to imprisonment for 6 months and a fine at level 4. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2021)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: Hong Kong coin (香港硬幣) means any coin which is legal tender in Hong Kong;
imitation Hong Kong coin (香港硬幣的仿製品) means anything which resembles a Hong Kong coin in shape, size and the substance of which it is made.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Prohibition of importation and exportation of counterfeit notes and coins
section.leadIn: A person who without the consent in writing of the Monetary Authority— (Amended 82 of 1992 s. 31)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: imports, lands or unloads a counterfeit of any currency note or protected coin; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exports a counterfeit of any currency note or protected coin,

section.continued: commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Powers of search, forfeiture, etc.

subsection.leadIn: If it appears to a magistrate, from information given him on oath, that there is reasonable cause to believe that a person has in his custody or under his control any thing which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is a counterfeit of a currency note or protected coin;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a reproduction made in contravention of section 103 or 104; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he or another has used after the commencement of the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1992 (49 of 1992) or intends to use, for the making of any such counterfeit or of any such reproduction,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing a police officer, customs officer or immigration officer to search for and seize that thing, and for that purpose to enter any premises specified in the warrant.

subsection.leadIn: A police officer, customs officer or immigration officer, at any time after seizing an object suspected of being a thing to which subsection (1) applies (whether or not the seizure was effected by virtue of a warrant under that subsection) may apply to a magistrate for an order under this subsection with respect to that object and the magistrate, if satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the object is a thing to which subsection (1) applies; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is in the public interest to do so,

subsection.continued: may, subject to subsection (4), make such order as he thinks fit for the forfeiture of the thing and its subsequent destruction or disposal.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), the court by or before which a person is convicted of an offence under this Part may order any object which it is satisfied relates to the commission of the offence to be forfeited and either destroyed or dealt with in such other manner as the court may direct.

If any person claiming to be the owner of or otherwise interested in any object liable to be forfeited under subsection (2) or (3) applies to be heard by a court or magistrate, as the case may be, the court or magistrate shall not order the object to be forfeited unless an opportunity has been given to that person to show cause why the order should not be made.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Designation of protected coins
section.content: The Monetary Authority may by order designate any coin, whether or not customarily used as money in any country or territory, as a protected coin for the purpose of this Part.

part.name: P12
part.heading: Sexual and Related Offences

section.name: s117
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: closure order (封閉令) means an order made under section 153A(2); (Added 69 of 1990 s. 2)
forfeiture order (沒收令) means an order made under section 153F(4); (Added 69 of 1990 s. 2)

mentally incapacitated person (精神上無行為能力的人) means a mentally disordered person or a mentally handicapped person (within the meaning of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136)) whose mental disorder or mental handicap, as the case may be, is of such a nature or degree that that person is incapable of living an independent life or guarding himself against serious exploitation, or will be so incapable when of an age to do so; (Added 81 of 1997 s. 59)

owner (擁有人) in relation to any premises means any person holding the premises direct from the Government, whether under lease, licence or otherwise, any mortgagee in possession and any person receiving the rent of the premises, solely or with another and on his behalf or that of any person, or who would receive the same if such premises were let to a tenant, and, where such owner as above defined cannot be found or ascertained, or is absent from Hong Kong or is under disability, also includes the agent of such owner; (Amended 29 of 1998 s. 105)
prostitute (娼妓) means a prostitute of either sex; (Added 90 of 1991 s. 2)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any place to which for the time being the public or a section of the public are entitled or permitted to have access, whether on payment or otherwise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a common part of any premises notwithstanding that the public or a section of the public are not entitled or permitted to have access to that common part or those premises; (Added 90 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.def: rape offence (強姦罪行) means any of the following, namely, rape, attempted rape, aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring rape or attempted rape, and incitement to rape; (Added 25 of 1978 s. 2) [cf. 1976 c. 82 s. 7(2) U.K.]

specified sexual offence (指明性罪行) means any of the following, namely, rape, non-consensual buggery, indecent assault, an attempt to commit any of those offences, aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission or attempted commission of any of those offences, and incitement to commit any of those offences; (Added 90 of 1991 s. 2)
suspension order (暫停執行令) means an order made under section 153I(4). (Added 69 of 1990 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part a person does an unlawful sexual act if, and only if, that person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has unlawful sexual intercourse;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: commits buggery or an act of gross indecency with a person of the opposite sex with whom that person may not have lawful sexual intercourse; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: commits buggery or an act of gross indecency with a person of the same sex. (Added 90 of 1991 s. 2)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.def: For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that for the purposes of sections 118, 119, 120 and 121 and without affecting the generality of any other provisions of this Part, unlawful sexual intercourse (非法性交、非法的性交) does not exclude sexual intercourse that a man has with his wife. (Added 23 of 2002 s. 11)

subsection.content: The use in any provision of this Part of the word “man” without the addition of the word “boy”, or vice versa, shall not prevent the provision applying to any person to whom it would have applied if both words had been used, and similarly with the words “woman” and “girl”.

subsection.leadIn: Premises, vessel or any place shall not be treated as a vice establishment for the purposes of this Part unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the premises, vessel or place are or is used wholly or mainly by 2 or more persons for the purposes of prostitution; or (Amended 90 of 1991 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the premises, vessel or place are or is used wholly or mainly for or in connexion with the organizing or arranging of prostitution.

section.name: s118
section.heading: Rape

subsection.content: A man who rapes a woman shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life. [cf. 1956 c. 69 s. 1 U.K.]
A man who induces a married woman to have sexual intercourse with him by impersonating her husband commits rape.

subsection.leadIn: A man commits rape if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he has unlawful sexual intercourse with a woman who at the time of the intercourse does not consent to it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: at that time he knows that she does not consent to the intercourse or he is reckless as to whether she consents to it. (Added 25 of 1978 s. 3) [cf. 1976 c. 82 s. 1(1) U.K.]

subsection.content: It is hereby declared that if at a trial for a rape offence the jury has to consider whether a man believed that a woman was consenting to sexual intercourse, the presence or absence of reasonable grounds for such a belief is a matter to which the jury is to have regard, in conjunction with any other relevant matters, in considering whether he so believed. (Added 25 of 1978 s. 3) [cf. 1976 c. 82 s. 1(2) U.K.]

In relation to such a trial as is mentioned in subsection (4) which is a trial in the District Court or a summary trial before a magistrate or in a juvenile court, references to the jury in that subsection shall be construed as references to the District Court, the magistrate or the juvenile court, as the case may be. (Added 25 of 1978 s. 3) [cf. 1976 c. 82 s. 7(3) U.K.]

section.name: s118A
section.heading: Non-consensual buggery
section.content: A person who commits buggery with another person who at the time of the buggery does not consent to it shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life.

section.name: s118B
section.heading: Assault with intent to commit buggery
section.content: A person who assaults another person with intent to commit buggery shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

section.name: s118C
section.heading: Homosexual buggery with or by man under 16
section.leadIn: A man who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: commits buggery with a man under the age of 16; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being under the age of 16 commits buggery with another man,

section.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life.

section.name: s118D
section.heading: Buggery with girl under 21
section.content: A man who commits buggery with a girl under the age of 21 shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life.

section.name: s118E
section.heading: Buggery with mentally incapacitated person

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a man who commits buggery with a mentally incapacitated person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.
A man who commits buggery with another person is not guilty of an offence under this section if he does not know and has no reason to suspect the other to be a mentally incapacitated person.
A man who commits buggery with a woman is not guilty of an offence under this section if he is, or believes on reasonable grounds that he is, married to that woman.

section.name: s118G
section.heading: Procuring others to commit homosexual buggery
section.content: A person who procures a man to commit an act of buggery with a third person, who is another man, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s118H
section.heading: Gross indecency with or by man under 16
section.leadIn: A man who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: commits an act of gross indecency with a man under the age of 16; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being under the age of 16 commits an act of gross indecency with another man,

section.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s118I
section.heading: Gross indecency by man with male mentally incapacitated person

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a man who commits an act of gross indecency with another man who is a mentally incapacitated person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years.

A man who commits an act of gross indecency with another man is not guilty of an offence under this section if he does not know and has no reason to suspect the other to be a mentally incapacitated person.

section.name: s118J
section.heading: Gross indecency by man with man otherwise than in private

subsection.content: A man who commits an act of gross indecency with another man otherwise than in private shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years.

subsection.leadIn: An act which would otherwise be treated for the purposes of this section as being done in private shall not be so treated if done—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in a lavatory or bathhouse to which the public have or are permitted to have access, whether on payment or otherwise.

subsection.def: In this section, bathhouse (浴室) means any premises or part of any premises maintained for the use of persons requiring a sauna, shower-bath, Turkish bath or other type of bath.

section.name: s118K
section.heading: Procuring gross indecency by man with man
section.content: A person who procures a man to commit an act of gross indecency with a third person, who is another man, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s118L
section.heading: Bestiality
section.content: A person who commits buggery with an animal shall be guilty of the crime of bestiality and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 10 years.

section.name: s118M
section.heading: Abolition of buggery at common law
section.content: The offence of buggery at common law is abolished.

section.name: s118N
section.heading: Past offences of buggery and gross indecency by males

subsection.leadIn: No person shall be prosecuted for an offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of buggery; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under the former section 51 of the Offences against the Person Ordinance (Cap. 212) (offences relating to gross indecency by male with male),

subsection.continued: committed before the commencement of the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1991 (90 of 1991) except in respect of an act that would have been an offence had the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1991 (90 of 1991) been in operation at the time of the act.

subsection.content: In this section, a reference to a former section is a reference to a section repealed by the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1991 (90 of 1991).

subsection.def: In this section, an offence (罪、罪行) includes attempting, inciting and conspiring to commit an offence, and aiding, abetting, counselling and procuring the commission or attempted commission of an offence.

section.name: s118O
section.heading: Abolition of presumption that boy under 14 incapable of sexual intercourse etc.

subsection.content: The presumption of law that a boy under the age of 14 is incapable of sexual intercourse, buggery or bestiality is abolished.
Subsection (1) does not apply in relation to any act done before the commencement date of this section.

For the purposes of subsection (2), if an act is alleged to have been done between 2 dates, one before and one after the commencement date of this section, the act is alleged to have been done before that commencement date.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Procurement by threats

subsection.content: A person who procures another person, by threats or intimidation, to do an unlawful sexual act in Hong Kong or elsewhere shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years. (Amended 90 of 1991 s. 4)

section.name: s120
section.heading: Procurement by false pretences

subsection.content: A person who procures another person, by false pretences or false representations, to do an unlawful sexual act in Hong Kong or elsewhere shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years. (Amended 90 of 1991 s. 5)

subsection.def: For the purposes of subsection (1), pretence (藉口) or representation (申述) includes a pretence or representation relating to the past, the present or the future and any pretence or representation as to the intention of the person using the pretence or representation or any other person.

section.name: s121
section.heading: Administering drugs to obtain or facilitate unlawful sexual act

subsection.content: A person who applies or administers to, or causes to be taken by, another person any drug, matter or thing with intent to stupefy or overpower that other person so as thereby to enable anyone to do an unlawful sexual act with that other person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years. (Amended 90 of 1991 s. 6)

section.name: s122
section.heading: Indecent assault

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), a person who indecently assaults another person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.
A person under the age of 16 cannot in law give any consent which would prevent an act being an assault for the purposes of this section.

A person is not, by virtue of subsection (2), guilty of indecently assaulting another person, if that person is, or believes on reasonable grounds that he or she is, married to that other person. (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 7)

A woman who is a mentally incapacitated person cannot in law give any consent which would prevent an act being an assault for the purposes of this section, but a person is only to be treated as guilty of indecently assaulting a mentally incapacitated person by reason of that incapacity to consent, if that person knew or had reason to suspect her to be a mentally incapacitated person. (Amended 81 of 1997 s. 59)

section.name: s123
section.heading: Intercourse with girl under 13
section.content: A man who has unlawful sexual intercourse with a girl under the age of 13 shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life.

section.name: s124
section.heading: Intercourse with girl under 16

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a man who has unlawful sexual intercourse with a girl under the age of 16 shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

Where a marriage is invalid under section 27(2) of the Marriage Ordinance (Cap. 181) by reason of the wife being under the age of 16, the invalidity shall not make the husband guilty of an offence under this section because he has sexual intercourse with her, if he believes her to be his wife and has reasonable cause for the belief.

section.name: s125
section.heading: Intercourse with mentally incapacitated person

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a man who has unlawful sexual intercourse with a woman who is a mentally incapacitated person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years. (Amended 68 of 1995 s. 49)

A man is not guilty of an offence under this section because he has unlawful sexual intercourse with a woman if he does not know and has no reason to suspect her to be a mentally incapacitated person.

section.sourceNote: (Added 1 of 1978 s. 6. Amended 31 of 1997 s. 4; 81 of 1997 s. 59)

section.name: s126
section.heading: Abduction of unmarried girl under 16

subsection.content: A person who, without lawful authority or excuse, takes an unmarried girl under the age of 16 out of the possession of her parent or guardian against the will of the parent or guardian shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

subsection.def: In subsection (1), guardian (監護人) means any person having the lawful care or charge of the girl.

section.name: s127
section.heading: Abduction of unmarried girl under 18 for sexual intercourse

subsection.content: A person who takes an unmarried girl under the age of 18 out of the possession of her parent or guardian against the will of the parent or guardian with the intention that she shall have unlawful sexual intercourse with men or with a particular man shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.def: In subsection (1), guardian (監護人) means any person having the lawful care or charge of the girl.

section.name: s128
section.heading: Abduction of mentally incapacitated person from parent or guardian for sexual act

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a person who takes a mentally incapacitated person out of the possession of her or his parent or guardian against the will of the parent or guardian with the intention that the mentally incapacitated person shall do an unlawful sexual act shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years. (Amended 31 of 1997 s. 6)

A person who takes another out of the possession of a parent or guardian is not guilty of an offence under this section if that person does not know and has no reason to suspect the other to be a mentally incapacitated person.

subsection.def: In this section, guardian (監護人) means any person having the lawful care or charge of the mentally incapacitated person.

part.crossHeading: Exploitation of other persons for sexual purposes

section.name: s129
section.heading: Trafficking in persons to or from Hong Kong

subsection.content: A person who takes part in bringing another person into, or taking another person out of, Hong Kong for the purpose of prostitution shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

It shall not be a defence to a charge under this section to prove that the other person consented to being brought into or taken out of Hong Kong whether or not she or he knew it was for the purpose of prostitution or that she or he received any advantage therefor.

section.sourceNote: (Added 1 of 1978 s. 6. Amended 90 of 1991 s. 9; 31 of 1997 s. 7)

section.name: s130
section.heading: Control over persons for purpose of unlawful sexual intercourse or prostitution

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: harbours another person or exercises control or direction over another person with the intention that that person shall do unlawful sexual acts with others; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: harbours another person or exercises control, direction or influence over another person for the purpose of or with a view to that person’s prostitution,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years. (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 10)

section.name: s131
section.heading: Causing prostitution

subsection.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: procures another person to become, in Hong Kong or elsewhere, a prostitute; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: procures another person to leave Hong Kong, intending that other person to become, elsewhere, an inmate of or frequent any premises, vessel or place kept as a vice establishment; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: procures another person to leave her or his usual place of abode in Hong Kong, intending that other person to become an inmate of or frequent any premises, vessel or place kept as a vice establishment, in Hong Kong or elsewhere, for the purpose of prostitution,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

section.sourceNote: (Added 1 of 1978 s. 6. Amended 90 of 1991 s. 11; 31 of 1997 s. 8)

section.name: s132
section.heading: Procurement of girl under 21

subsection.content: A person who procures a girl under the age of 21 to have unlawful sexual intercourse in Hong Kong or elsewhere with a third person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Procurement of mentally incapacitated person

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a person who procures a woman who is a mentally incapacitated person to have unlawful sexual intercourse in Hong Kong or elsewhere with a third person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years. (Amended 31 of 1997 s. 9)

A person shall not be guilty of an offence under this section because he procures a mentally incapacitated person to have unlawful sexual intercourse, if he does not know and has no reason to suspect her to be a mentally incapacitated person.

section.name: s134
section.heading: Detention for intercourse or in vice establishment

subsection.leadIn: A person who in any manner or by any means detains another person against her or his will—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the intention that the other person shall do an unlawful sexual act; or (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 12)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on any premises or vessel, or in any place, kept as a vice establishment,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is on any premises or vessel for the purpose of doing an unlawful sexual act or is on any premises or vessel, or in any place, kept as a vice establishment, another person shall be deemed for the purposes of subsection (1) to detain that person there if, with the intention of compelling or inducing that person to remain there, the other person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: withholds from that person any of that person’s clothes or other property; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: threatens that person with legal proceedings in the event of that person taking away clothes provided for that person by the other person or on the other person’s directions. (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 12)

subsection.content: A person shall not be liable to any legal proceedings, whether civil or criminal, for taking away or being found in possession of any clothes she or he needed to enable her or him to leave premises or a vessel on which she or he was being detained for the purpose of doing an unlawful sexual act or to leave any premises, vessel or place kept as a vice establishment.

section.name: s135
section.heading: Causing or encouraging prostitution of, intercourse with, or indecent assault on, girl or boy under 16

subsection.content: A person who causes or encourages the prostitution of or an unlawful sexual act with a girl or boy under the age of 16 for whom that person is responsible shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years. (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 13. Amended 31 of 1997 s. 10)

Where a girl or boy is a prostitute or has done an unlawful sexual act, a person shall be deemed for the purposes of this section to have caused or encouraged the same if that person knowingly allowed the girl or boy to consort with, or to enter or continue in the employment of, any prostitute or person of known immoral character. (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 13)

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), the persons who for the purposes of this section are to be treated as responsible for a girl or boy are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any person who is her or his parent or legal guardian;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person who has actual possession or control of her or him, or to whose charge she or he has been committed by her or his parent or legal guardian or by a person having the custody of her or him; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other person who has the custody, charge or care of her or him.

subsection.def: In subsection (3), parent (父母) does not include, in relation to any girl or boy, a person deprived of her or his custody by order of a court of competent jurisdiction but, subject to that, in the case of a girl or boy who has been adopted under the Adoption Ordinance (Cap. 290) means her or his adopters and in the case of a girl or boy who is illegitimate, and has not been so adopted, means her or his mother and any person who has been adjudged to be her or his putative father.

section.name: s136
section.heading: Causing or encouraging prostitution of mentally incapacitated person

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), a person who causes or encourages the prostitution in Hong Kong or elsewhere of a mentally incapacitated person shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years. (Amended 90 of 1991 s. 14)

A person who causes or encourages the prostitution of another is not guilty of an offence under this section if that person does not know and has no reason to suspect the other to be a mentally incapacitated person. (Replaced 90 of 1991 s. 14)

section.name: s137
section.heading: Living on earnings of prostitution of others

subsection.content: A person who knowingly lives wholly or in part on the earnings of prostitution of another shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

For the purposes of subsection (1), a person who lives with or is habitually in the company of a prostitute, or who exercises control, direction or influence over another person’s movements in a way which shows he or she is aiding, abetting or compelling that other person’s prostitution with others, shall be presumed to be knowingly living on the earnings of prostitution, unless he or she proves the contrary.

section.sourceNote: (Added 1 of 1978 s. 6. Amended 90 of 1991 s. 15; 31 of 1997 s. 11)

section.name: s138A
section.heading: Use, procurement or offer of persons under 18 for making pornography or for live pornographic performances

subsection.leadIn: Any person who uses, procures or offers another person who is under the age of 18 for making pornography, or for a live pornographic performance, in which that other person is or is to be pornographically depicted, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the offence is committed in relation to a person under the age of 16, to a fine of $3,000,000 and to imprisonment for 10 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the offence is committed in relation to a person of the age of 16 or above but under 18, to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence to a charge of using or procuring a person of the age of 16 or above but under 18 for making pornography for the defendant to establish that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the time of the alleged offence, the person pornographically depicted for making pornography consented to being so depicted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the pornography so made is solely for the personal use of the defendant and the person depicted.

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence to a charge of using or procuring a person of the age of 16 or above but under 18 for a live pornographic performance for the defendant to establish that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at the time of the alleged offence, the person pornographically depicted for the performance consented to being so depicted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the audience of the performance consisted of the defendant only.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section, to depict a person pornographically means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to visually depict a person as being engaged in explicit sexual conduct, whether or not the person is in fact engaged in such conduct; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to visually depict, in a sexual manner or context, the genitals or anal region of a person or, in the case of a female person, her breast,

subsection.continued: but, for the avoidance of doubt, a depiction for a genuine family purpose does not, merely because it depicts any part of the body referred to in paragraph (b), fall within that paragraph.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: live pornographic performance (真人色情表演) includes any play, show, exhibition, act, entertainment, presentation, display or other performance of any kind in which a person is pornographically depicted;

def.name: Pornography

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a photograph, film, computer-generated image or other visual depiction that depicts a person pornographically, whether it is made or generated by electronic or any other means and whether or not it has been modified; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: anything that incorporates a photograph, film, image or depiction referred to in paragraph (a),

def.continued: and includes data stored in a form that is capable of conversion into a photograph, film, image or depiction referred to in paragraph (a) and anything containing such data.

section.name: s139
section.heading: Keeping a vice establishment

subsection.leadIn: A person who on any occasion— (Amended 69 of 1990 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: keeps any premises, vessel or place as a vice establishment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: manages or assists in the management, or is otherwise in charge or control, of any premises, vessel or place kept as a vice establishment,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to imprisonment for 3 years; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a charge under this section is preferred against a person or is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is acquitted or convicted of, or successfully appeals against a conviction for, an offence under this section,

subsection.continued: section 145A applies. (Added 69 of 1990 s. 3)

part.crossHeading: Use of premises, etc. for illicit sexual purposes

section.name: s140
section.heading: Permitting girl or boy under 13 to resort to or be on premises or vessel for intercourse
section.content: An owner or occupier of any premises or vessel, and any person who manages or assists in the management or control of any premises or vessel, who induces or knowingly suffers a girl or boy under the age of 13 to resort to or be on such premises or vessel for the purpose of doing an unlawful sexual act or for the purpose of prostitution shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life.

section.name: s141
section.heading: Permitting young person to resort to or be on premises or vessel for intercourse, prostitution, buggery or homosexual act
section.leadIn: An owner or occupier of any premises or vessel, and any person who manages or assists in the management or control of any premises or vessel, who induces or knowingly suffers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a girl under the age of 16 to resort to or be on such premises or vessel for the purpose of having unlawful sexual intercourse with a man or for the purpose of prostitution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a girl or boy under the age of 21 to resort to or be on such premises or vessel for the purpose of committing buggery with a man; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a boy under the age of 21 to resort to or be on such premises or vessel for the purpose of committing an act of gross indecency with a man,

section.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 14 years.

section.name: s142
section.heading: Permitting mentally incapacitated person to resort to or be on premises or vessel for intercourse, prostitution or homosexual act

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), an owner or occupier of any premises or vessel, and any person who manages or assists in the management or control of any premises or vessel, who induces or knowingly suffers—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a woman who is a mentally incapacitated person to resort to or be on such premises or vessel for the purpose of having unlawful sexual intercourse with a man or for the purpose of prostitution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a man who is a mentally incapacitated person to resort to or be on such premises or vessel for the purpose of committing buggery with a man or an act of gross indecency with a man,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years.

subsection.content: A person who induces or knowingly suffers another to resort to or be on any premises or vessel is not guilty of an offence under this section if that person does not know and has no reason to suspect the other to be a mentally incapacitated person.

section.name: s143
section.heading: Letting premises for use as a vice establishment

subsection.leadIn: A person who, being the owner or tenant of any premises or his agent— (Amended 69 of 1990 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: lets the whole or part of the premises with the knowledge that it is to be kept, in whole or in part, as a vice establishment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the whole or part of the premises is used as a vice establishment, is wilfully a party to that use continuing,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a charge under this section is preferred against a person or is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is acquitted or convicted of, or successfully appeals against a conviction for, an offence under this section,

subsection.continued: section 145A applies. (Added 69 of 1990 s. 3)

section.name: s144
section.heading: Tenant etc. permitting premises or vessel to be kept as a vice establishment

subsection.leadIn: A person who— (Amended 69 of 1990 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being the tenant or occupier, or person in charge, of any premises permits or suffers the whole or part of the premises to be kept as a vice establishment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being the owner, or the master or other person in charge, of any vessel permits or suffers the whole or part of the vessel to be kept as a vice establishment,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a charge under this section is preferred against a person or is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is acquitted or convicted of, or successfully appeals against a conviction for, an offence under this section,

subsection.continued: section 145A applies. (Added 69 of 1990 s. 3)

section.name: s145
section.heading: Tenant etc. permitting premises or vessel to be used for prostitution

subsection.leadIn: A person who— (Amended 69 of 1990 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: being the tenant or occupier, or person in charge, of any premises permits or suffers the whole or part of the premises to be used for the purposes of habitual prostitution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: being the owner, or the master or other person in charge, of any vessel permits or suffers the whole or part of the vessel to be used for the purpose of habitual prostitution,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 7 years.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a charge under this section is preferred against a person or is withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person is acquitted or convicted of, or successfully appeals against a conviction for, an offence under this section,

subsection.continued: section 145A applies. (Added 69 of 1990 s. 3)

section.name: s145A
section.heading: Notification of charge, conviction etc.

subsection.content: Where a charge under section 139, 143, 144 or 145 is preferred against a person or is withdrawn, the Commissioner of Police shall as soon as reasonably practicable send to the appropriate person a notice in writing stating that fact and the date on which it occurred and setting out the specified information.

Where a person is acquitted or convicted by a court or magistrate of, or successfully appeals against a conviction for, an offence under section 139, 143, 144 or 145, the court or magistrate or the appellate court (as the case may be) shall as soon as reasonably practicable send a notice in writing to the appropriate person stating that fact and the date on which it occurred and setting out the specified information.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an offence alleged or proved to have been committed in relation to any premises or place other than a vessel, the Land Registrar; and (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an offence alleged or proved to have been committed in relation to a vessel, the Director of Marine;

subsection.def: specified information (指明的資料) means the address of the premises or place, or the identity of the vessel, in relation to which the offence is or was alleged or proved to have been committed and, where the alleged offence or the offence related to part of any premises, place or vessel, the location of that part.

section.name: s146
section.heading: Indecent conduct towards child under 16

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), a person who commits an act of gross indecency with or towards a child under the age of 16, or who incites a child under the age of 16 to commit such an act with or towards him or her or another, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 10 years. (Amended 90 of 1991 s. 20; 31 of 1997 s. 16)
It shall not be a defence to a charge under this section to prove that the child consented to the act of gross indecency.

A person who commits an act of gross indecency with or towards a child or who incites a child to commit such an act with or towards him or her is not guilty of an offence under this section if that person is, or believes on reasonable grounds that he or she is, married to the child. (Added 90 of 1991 s. 20)

section.name: s147
section.heading: Soliciting for an immoral purpose

subsection.leadIn: A person who in a public place or in view of the public—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: solicits for any immoral purpose; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: loiters for the purpose of soliciting for any immoral purpose,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended 69 of 1990 s. 5; E.R. 4 of 2021)

def.name: AnyImmoralPurpose
def.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1) but without prejudice to the generality of the expression any immoral purpose, each of the following is immoral—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: buggery by a man with another man;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an act of gross indecency by a man with another man. (Added 90 of 1991 s. 21)

section.name: s147A
section.heading: Prohibition of signs advertising prostitution

subsection.content: Any person who publicly displays, or causes or permits the public display of, a sign that advertises, or may reasonably be understood to advertise, the services of a prostitute or of a person who organizes or arranges prostitution shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to imprisonment for 12 months. (Amended 31 of 1997 s. 17)

Where a sign displayed in contravention of subsection (1) advertises, or may reasonably be understood to advertise, that the services of a prostitute or of a person who organizes or arranges prostitution are available at a place, any person who keeps, or manages or is otherwise in charge or control of, that place shall, until the contrary is proved, be presumed to have caused the display of the sign.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a sign is publicly displayed if, and only if, it can be seen from—

subparagraph.content: any place to which for the time being the public or a section of the public are entitled or permitted to have access, whether on payment or otherwise; or
a common part of any premises notwithstanding that the public or a section of the public are not entitled or permitted to have access to that common part or those premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in deciding how a sign may reasonably be understood regard may be had to—

subparagraph.content: all aspects of the sign, including its size, colour, shape and design;
the location of the sign;
the user of any place that the sign advertises; and
the services offered by any person whose services the sign advertises,

paragraph.continued: and to any other relevant circumstances.

section.name: s147B
section.heading: Removal of signs advertising prostitution

subsection.content: Without prejudice to section 152 or 153, where a police officer of the rank of chief inspector or above reasonably believes that a sign is displayed in contravention of section 147A, he may in writing authorize any other police officer to cause the sign to be taken away or effaced.

A police officer authorizing another police officer under subsection (1) to cause a sign to be taken away may in writing authorize him to cause any structure supporting the sign to be taken away and, where he does so, a reference in this section or in section 147C, 147D, 147E or 147F to a sign shall include a reference to the supporting structure.

A police officer authorized under subsection (1), and any person whose assistance he may require, may take such measures as are necessary in order to take away or efface the sign, as the case may be, but may enter any premises or place by virtue of this subsection only under a warrant issued under subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may, if satisfied by information on oath that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is reasonable cause to believe that a sign is displayed in contravention of section 147A; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: entry into any premises or place is reasonably necessary in order to take away or efface that sign,

subsection.continued: issue a warrant authorizing a police officer, and any person whose assistance that officer may require, to enter such premises or place, by force if necessary.

subsection.leadIn: Where a sign is taken away under subsection (3), the Commissioner of Police—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may, subject to paragraph (b) and sections 147C and 147D, detain the sign;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: shall give possession of the sign to any person who satisfies the Commissioner that—

subparagraph.content: he is the owner of the sign or was, before the sign was taken away, entitled to possession of the sign; and
the sign was not, before being taken away, being displayed in contravention of section 147A;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: may, if—

subparagraph.content: he has detained the sign for at least one month;
he is not obliged under paragraph (b) or section 147C or 147D to give possession of the sign to any person; and
he is not aware of any pending application under section 147C for the recovery of the sign, or of any pending charge under section 147A,

paragraph.continued: order the sign to be destroyed, sold or otherwise disposed of as he thinks fit.

subsection.content: Where a sign is sold under subsection (5)(c) the sale proceeds shall be paid into the general revenue.

section.name: s147C
section.heading: Application for recovery of sign

subsection.content: Where a sign has been taken away under section 147B, a person claiming to be the owner of the sign or to be entitled to possession of the sign may, within one month after the removal, apply to a magistrate for an order that the Commissioner of Police give possession of the sign to him.

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application under this section, the magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fix a date for the hearing of the application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify the Commissioner of Police of the application and of the date of the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate may order the Commissioner of Police to give possession of the sign to the applicant if, after hearing an application under this section and any representations made by or on behalf of the Commissioner of Police, the magistrate is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant is the owner of the sign or was, before the sign was taken away, entitled to possession of the sign; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sign was not, before being taken away, being displayed in contravention of section 147A.

section.name: s147D
section.heading: Order concerning sign following acquittal under section 147A
section.leadIn: Where a sign has been taken away under section 147B and a person is acquitted of an offence under section 147A in respect of that sign, the court or magistrate by whom he is acquitted may order that the Commissioner of Police give possession of the sign to him or any other person if (but only if) the court or magistrate is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he or that other person, as the case may be, is the owner of the sign or was, before the sign was taken away, entitled to possession of the sign; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the sign was not, before being taken away, being displayed in contravention of section 147A.

section.name: s147E
section.heading: Recovery of expenses from convicted person

subsection.leadIn: Where expense is incurred—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in taking away a sign under section 147B; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in carrying out remedial works to a building that were reasonably necessary as a result of a sign being so taken away,

subsection.continued: a court or magistrate may, on the conviction of any person for an offence under section 147A in respect of that sign, order that person to pay to the person who incurred the expense such amount in respect of the expense as it or he thinks reasonable.

subsection.content: A court may enforce payment of any amount ordered to be paid under subsection (1) in the same manner as if it were a judgment debt.

section.name: s147F
section.heading: Obstruction
section.content: Any person who obstructs, or fails to comply with any reasonable requirement of, any police officer acting, or any person assisting a police officer, under section 147B(3) or under a warrant issued under section 147B(4) shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s148
section.heading: Indecency in public

subsection.content: A person who, without lawful authority or excuse, in any public place or in view of the public indecently exposes any part of his body shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 1 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2021)
A person under the age of 12 shall not be guilty of an offence under subsection (1) by reason only of his bathing unclothed.

section.name: s149
section.heading: Conviction for offence other than that charged

subsection.content: If on the trial of a charge for an offence specified in the second column of Schedule 1 the accused is acquitted, but it is proved that the accused is guilty of any offence specified opposite thereto in the third column of Schedule 1 or of being party to any such offence, he shall be convicted of such offence or of being a party to any such offence and shall be liable to be punished accordingly. (Amended 31 of 2003 s. 15)
Nothing in this section shall exclude the application to any offence of any other law authorizing a court to find a person guilty of an offence other than that with which he is charged.

section.name: s150
section.heading: Proof of exceptions
section.content: Where in any section in this Part the description of an offence is expressed to be subject to exceptions mentioned in the section, proof of the exception is to lie on the person relying on it.

section.name: s151
section.heading: Power of search in case of living on another’s earnings of prostitution
section.content: Where it is made to appear to a magistrate by information on oath that there is reasonable cause to suspect that any premises or vessel is used by a person for the purpose of prostitution, and that another person residing in or frequenting the premises or vessel is living wholly or in part on that person’s earnings, the magistrate may issue a warrant authorizing a police officer to enter and search such premises or vessel and to arrest that other person.

section.name: s152
section.heading: General power of search and seizure

subsection.content: If a police officer of the rank of superintendent or above has reason to suspect that an offence under this Part has been or is being committed in or in respect of or in connexion with any premises or place or any vessel, he may in writing authorize any police officer for the purposes of this section.

subsection.leadIn: A police officer authorized under subsection (1) for the purposes of this section, and any other police officer assisting him may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter, by force if necessary, the premises or place or vessel specified in the authorization and search the same;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: search any person found in such premises or place or vessel;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: seize and detain anything found in such premises or place or vessel which appears to him to be or to contain evidence of an offence under this Part.

subsection.content: No person shall be searched under subsection (2) except by a person of the same sex.

section.name: s153
section.heading: Seizure and forfeiture in respect of vice establishment

subsection.content: Without prejudice to section 152, if a police officer reasonably suspects that any premises, vessel or place is being kept as a vice establishment, he may seize and detain anything found in such premises, vessel or place, or on any person found in such premises, vessel or place, which appears to him to have been used in or for or in connexion with the commission of an offence under section 139.

If, in any proceedings for an offence under section 139, 143 or 144 or otherwise on application by or on behalf of the Commissioner of Police, a court or magistrate is satisfied that anything in the possession of the court or magistrate or the police, not being immovable property, has been used in or for or in connexion with the commission of an offence under section 139, the court or magistrate may order that it be forfeited to the Government, whether or not any person has been convicted of an offence under section 139. (Amended 13 of 1999 s. 3)

part.crossHeading: Closure of premises and forfeiture of vessel in respect of which certain offences committed

section.name: s153A
section.heading: Closure of premises in respect of which certain offences committed

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is convicted by a court or magistrate of an offence under section 139, 143, 144 or 145 of this Ordinance, in relation to any premises or place other than a vessel; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the court or magistrate is satisfied—

subparagraph.content: that the offence was committed within a period beginning 4 months after and ending 16 months after a conviction of that or any other person for an offence under any of the provisions referred to in paragraph (a) in relation to the whole or a part of those premises or that place (whether or not a closure order was made on the basis of that and any other conviction); and

subparagraph.leadIn: that within 2 weeks after the date of the conviction referred to in subparagraph (i), a notice complying with subsection (4) was—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: affixed to a conspicuous part of the premises or place to which that conviction related; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: published in one newspaper published in Hong Kong in the English language and one newspaper so published in the Chinese language,

subsection.continued: this section applies to the premises or place referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: Where this section applies to any premises or place the court or magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in accordance with section 153B, make a closure order in respect of the premises or place;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as soon as reasonably practicable, send a copy of the order, sealed with the seal of the court or signed by the magistrate, to the Land Registrar; (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: have the same power to sentence or otherwise deal with the convicted person as if a closure order were not being made; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: leave the closure order out of account in determining the appropriate sentence or other manner of dealing with the convicted person.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: under section 143 a person who is the owner or tenant of any premises or his agent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: under section 144 or 145 a person who is the tenant or occupier, or person in charge, of any premises,

subsection.continued: is convicted of an offence in respect of part of those premises, the conviction shall be treated as relating only to that part of those premises.

subsection.leadIn: A notice complying with this subsection shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be addressed to the tenant and the owner of the premises or place to which the conviction referred to in subsection (1)(b)(i) relates (it being unnecessary to name those persons);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state that a person has been convicted of an offence in relation to the premises or place and state the nature, date, and the name and address of the person convicted, of the offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: state that if, within a period beginning 4 months after the date of that conviction and ending 16 months after that date, any person commits an offence under section 139, 143, 144 or 145 of this Ordinance, in relation to the whole or a part of those premises or that place, a closure order will be made in respect of the premises or place to which that second offence relates; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: set out the sections referred to in paragraph (c) or, if the notice is published contemporaneously with another notice under subsection (1)(b)(ii) in the same newspapers and the sections referred to in paragraph (c) are already set out in that notice, contain a direction to refer to that notice for the full text of those sections. (Amended 32 of 2000 s. 13)

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b)(ii), a certificate purporting to be signed by a public officer who states in that certificate that he affixed a notice in accordance with that subsection shall be evidence of the facts stated in the certificate relating to that affixing.

subsection.def: In sections 153B, 153I and 153J, premises (處所) means the premises or place to which the conviction referred to in subsection (1)(a) relates.

section.name: s153B
section.heading: Closure order

subsection.leadIn: A closure order shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identify the premises to which it relates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state that the premises are to be closed for 6 months and that any person who enters or is in the premises after they have been closed or who, without lawful authority or reasonable excuse, interferes with anything used to close the premises commits an offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order the closure of the premises; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: state that any person who is a mortgagee or chargee of the premises or who would, if the premises were not closed,—

subparagraph.content: be entitled or permitted to occupy or possess the premises; or
be the immediate landlord of the occupier of the premises,

paragraph.continued: may, in accordance with section 153I, apply for the order to be suspended.

subsection.leadIn: A court or magistrate making a closure order in respect of any premises—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall issue a warrant to any bailiff, commanding him to close the premises and to affix a copy of the closure order to a conspicuous part of the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may direct that the warrant is not to be executed until after a specified period not exceeding 3 days.

subsection.leadIn: A bailiff by whom a warrant issued under this section is executed in respect of any premises, and any person whose assistance may be necessary, may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter (by force if necessary) any place in order to effect the closure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: evict persons from the premises;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: use such reasonable force and take such reasonable measures as are necessary to effect the closure.

section.name: s153C
section.heading: Protection of bona fide purchaser or mortgagee

subsection.content: Where a closure order has been made in respect of any premises or place, any person to whom this section applies may, in accordance with section 153L, apply in writing for the closure order to be rescinded.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to any person who became a bona fide purchaser, mortgagee or chargee for valuable consideration of an interest in the premises or place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after another person had been convicted of an offence or had been charged with an offence for which he was subsequently convicted, that conviction being one upon which the closure order was based; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: before a notice relating to that conviction or charge was registered in accordance with section 153M.

subsection.content: An application under this section shall state the name, address and business or occupation of the applicant and, where the applicant is an individual, be accompanied by a copy of a document which is proof of his identity for the purposes of Part IVA of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115).

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application under this section the court or magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appoint a date for the hearing of the application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send a copy of the application and of the accompanying document of identity to the Commissioner of Police and inform him of the date of the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: A court or magistrate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after hearing an application under this section and after hearing any representations made by or on behalf of the Commissioner of Police;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if satisfied that, at the time the applicant became a bona fide purchaser, mortgagee or chargee of an interest in the premises or place, he did not know of the charge or conviction (as the case may be) in relation to which a notice had not been registered in accordance with section 153M; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if satisfied that, having regard to all the circumstances, it would be unjust for the applicant to be affected by the closure order,

subsection.continued: may rescind the closure order.

subsection.content: A court or magistrate that rescinds a closure order under subsection (5) shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, send to the Land Registrar and to the Commissioner of Police a notice in writing, sealed with the seal of the court or signed by the magistrate, stating that fact. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

section.name: s153D
section.heading: Forfeiture of vessels in respect of which certain offences committed

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person is convicted by a court or magistrate of an offence under section 139, 144 or 145 of this Ordinance, in relation to a vessel or part of a vessel; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the court or magistrate is satisfied—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that the offence was committed within a period beginning 4 months after and ending 16 months after a conviction of that or any other person for an offence under any of the provisions referred to in paragraph (a) in relation to that vessel or any part of that vessel; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: that within 2 weeks after the date of the conviction referred to in subparagraph (i), a notice complying with subsection (3) was—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: served on the owner of the vessel; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: published in the Gazette and in one newspaper published in Hong Kong in the English language and one newspaper so published in the Chinese language,

subsection.continued: this section applies to that vessel.

subsection.leadIn: Where this section applies to any vessel the court or magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on an application by the Commissioner of Police, declare that the vessel is liable to forfeiture;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: as soon as reasonably practicable, send a notice in writing to the Director of Marine identifying the vessel and stating that it has been declared under this section to be liable to forfeiture;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: have the same power to sentence or otherwise deal with the convicted person as if the vessel were not so liable; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: leave the liability to forfeiture out of account in determining the appropriate sentence or other manner of dealing with the convicted person.

subsection.leadIn: A notice complying with this section shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be addressed to the owner of the vessel (it being unnecessary to name the owner);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: state that a person has been convicted of an offence in relation to the vessel and state the nature, date, and the name and address of the person convicted, of the offence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: state that if, within a period beginning 4 months after the date of that conviction and ending 16 months after that date, any person commits an offence under section 139, 144 or 145 of this Ordinance, in relation to the vessel, and is convicted of that offence, the vessel will be liable to forfeiture; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: set out the sections referred to in paragraph (c).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b)(ii) and section 153E, a notice is duly served on the owner of a vessel if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is delivered to him, or to the person whom the Commissioner believes to be the owner;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is sent by registered post addressed to such person at the place of residence or business of such person, if any, known to the Commissioner; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where in the opinion of the Commissioner it is not practicable to serve the notice in accordance with paragraph (a) or (b) the notice is exhibited in the Marine Department in a place to which the public have access for a period of not less than 7 days.

section.name: s153E
section.heading: Procedure in respect of forfeiture of vessels

subsection.content: Where a court or magistrate declares that a vessel is liable to forfeiture under section 153D(2), the Commissioner may seize and detain the vessel or (if the vessel is already in his custody) continue to detain the vessel, and if he does so he shall, within 2 weeks of the seizure or declaration (whichever is the later), serve notice of the declaration on the owner of the vessel.

subsection.leadIn: Within 7 days after the service of a notice under subsection (1), notice of the declaration shall be published—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Gazette; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in one newspaper published in Hong Kong in the English language and one newspaper so published in the Chinese language.

subsection.leadIn: Where a notice has been served under subsection (1), any person who has a claim (in this section and section 153F referred to as the claimant) may within 30 days after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of the notice, if it was served in accordance with section 153D(4)(a) or (b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the first day on which the notice was exhibited, if it was served in accordance with section 153D(4)(c),

subsection.continued: give notice in writing to the Commissioner that he claims that the vessel should not be forfeited.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (3) shall state an address within Hong Kong at which the claimant may be served in any proceedings relating to the forfeiture of the vessel and in any such proceedings a document addressed to the claimant and sent by post to, or delivered at, that address shall for the purposes of this section and section 153F be deemed to be duly served on the claimant.

The Commissioner may, at any time before the end of the appropriate period of time specified in subsection (3) for the giving of a notice of claim, terminate the seizure of the vessel by serving notice to that effect on the owner in accordance with section 153D(4), or in a similar manner on the person in possession of the vessel at the time it was seized; and within 14 days of so terminating the seizure of the vessel, the Commissioner shall release the vessel to the owner or to such person and publish notice of the termination of the seizure in the manner provided in subsection (2).

If, at the end of the appropriate period of time specified in subsection (3) for the giving of a notice of claim, no such notice has been given in writing to the Commissioner, the vessel shall be forfeited.

subsection.leadIn: A person has a claim for the purposes of this section and section 153F if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he is the owner of the vessel, or has an interest in the vessel, or is the agent of the owner; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he was in possession of the vessel at the time it was seized.

section.name: s153F
section.heading: Determination of application for forfeiture

subsection.content: Where a notice of claim is given under section 153E(3) and the Commissioner does not terminate the seizure under section 153E(5), the Commissioner shall apply to a magistrate for the forfeiture of the vessel.
An application under subsection (1) is, for the purpose of section 8 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), a complaint.

When an application under subsection (1) is made to a magistrate, the magistrate shall issue a summons to any claimant requiring him to appear before a magistrate on the hearing of the application and shall cause a copy of the summons to be served on the Commissioner.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of an application under subsection (1), the magistrate may order that the vessel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be forfeited;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be released to the owner or his agent subject to any condition that he may specify in the order; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be disposed of in such manner and subject to such conditions as he may specify in the order.

subsection.leadIn: On the hearing of an application made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certified true copy of the record of any proceedings, including the decision of the court, in respect of an offence committed in relation to the vessel shall be admissible in evidence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a certificate purporting to be signed by a public officer who states in the certificate that he effected service in accordance with section 153D(4) shall be evidence of the facts stated in the certificate and relating to that service; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Part IV of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) (which relates to the admissibility of hearsay evidence in civil proceedings) shall apply as if the proceedings were civil proceedings.

section.name: s153G
section.heading: Claims for return of forfeited vessel

subsection.content: The owner of any vessel forfeited under section 153E or his agent may within 6 weeks after the vessel was forfeited give notice in writing to the Commissioner of his intention to submit to the Chief Executive a moral claim in respect of the forfeited vessel.

subsection.leadIn: Where the owner of a vessel or his agent has given notice under subsection (1) and has submitted a moral claim to the Chief Executive by lodging it with the Chief Secretary for Administration within 1 month from the date of that notice, the Chief Executive may— (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: a
