paragraph.content: order the return of the forfeited vessel to the claimant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct that the claim be referred to the Chief Executive in Council.

subsection.leadIn: Where a claim is referred to the Chief Executive in Council under subsection (2) he may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: order the return of the forfeited vessel to the claimant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: reject the claim.

section.name: s153H
section.heading: Effect of appeals and applications on closure orders, and forfeiture orders and declarations

subsection.content: A closure order or forfeiture order shall be enforced and a declaration under section 153D(2) shall remain in effect even if an appeal is pending in respect of a conviction upon which it is based.
A closure order shall be enforced even if an application has been made under section 153C for the order to be rescinded or under section 153I for the order to be suspended.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person successfully appeals against a conviction upon which a closure order, a declaration under section 153D(2) or a forfeiture order is based, the appellate court shall rescind the order or declaration unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that or any other person was convicted in the same proceedings of an offence of which he remains convicted and, as a result, the closure order, declaration or forfeiture order could have been made without reference to the first-mentioned conviction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the appellate court substitutes a verdict of guilty of another offence upon which the closure order, declaration or forfeiture order could, if the person had originally been convicted of that offence, have been based.

subsection.content: Where a court rescinds a closure order under subsection (3), it shall as soon as reasonably practicable send a notice in writing, sealed with the seal of the court, to the Land Registrar stating that fact. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

Where a court rescinds a declaration under subsection (3), it shall as soon as reasonably practicable send a notice in writing, sealed with the seal of the court, to the Director of Marine stating that fact.

section.name: s153I
section.heading: Suspension order

subsection.leadIn: Where a closure order has been made in respect of any premises, any person who is a mortgagee or chargee of the premises or who would, if the premises were not closed,—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be entitled or permitted to occupy or possess the premises; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be the immediate landlord of the occupier of the premises,

subsection.continued: may, in accordance with section 153L, apply in writing for the closure order to be suspended.

subsection.leadIn: An application under this section shall state—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the name, address and business or occupation of the person who is proposed to be the occupier of the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the purpose for which it is proposed the premises be used,

subsection.continued: during the suspension of the closure order and, where the proposed occupier is an individual, be accompanied by a copy of a document which is proof of his identity for the purposes of Part IVA of the Immigration Ordinance (Cap. 115).

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application under this section the court or magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appoint a date for the hearing of the application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send a copy of the application and of the accompanying document of identity to the Commissioner of Police and inform him of the date of the hearing.

subsection.leadIn: A court or magistrate may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after hearing an application under this section and after hearing any representations made by or on behalf of the Commissioner of Police; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if satisfied that the proposed user of the premises by the proposed occupier would not be likely to cause a nuisance or annoyance to any person residing nearby,

subsection.continued: make an order suspending the closure order for 2 years (but not for a shorter period).

subsection.leadIn: A court or magistrate making a suspension order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall attach a condition to the order to the effect that the premises are, during the suspension, to be used only for the purpose proposed and, when occupied, to be occupied by the person proposed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: may attach any other conditions to the order as it or he thinks fit, including the following conditions—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that if there is a breach of the condition referred to in paragraph (a), a person will forfeit a specified sum of money;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that a person gives security, in such a manner and such amount as may be specified, in respect of any sum that he may forfeit as a result of a breach of the condition referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.content: A court may enforce payment of any sum of money that is forfeited as a result of a breach of any condition attached to a suspension order in the same manner as if it were a judgment debt and any money recovered shall be paid into the general revenue.
Where a closure order is suspended and is not revived under section 153K, the order shall cease to have effect at the end of the 2-year period for which it was suspended.

A court or magistrate making a suspension order shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, send to the Land Registrar and to the Commissioner of Police a copy of the order, sealed with the seal of the court or signed by the magistrate. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

section.name: s153J
section.heading: Variation of conditions attached to suspension order

subsection.content: Any person specified in subsection (2) may, in accordance with section 153L, apply in writing for a variation of any condition attached to a suspension order and section 153I shall apply, with the necessary modifications, to such an application.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1) may be made by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person liable to be penalised in the event of a breach of a condition attached to the suspension order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person who is a mortgagee or chargee of the premises or who is or would, if the variation applied for were granted, be—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: entitled or permitted to occupy or possess the premises; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the immediate landlord of the occupier of the premises.

section.name: s153K
section.heading: Revival of closure order

subsection.content: Where a closure order has been suspended under section 153I, any police officer of or above the rank of chief inspector may, in accordance with section 153L, apply in writing for the closure order to be revived on the basis that a condition attached to the suspension order has been broken.

subsection.leadIn: Upon receipt of an application made under subsection (1) the court or magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appoint a date for the hearing of the application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: issue a summons to the occupier of the premises, the immediate landlord of the occupier of the premises, and any person liable to be penalised in the event of a breach of a condition attached to the suspension order, requiring them to appear before the court or magistrate on the hearing of the application.

subsection.leadIn: An application under this section is, for the purposes of section 8 of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), a complaint, but—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the place of abode of the immediate landlord of the occupier of the premises is not known, a summons to him may be served on him by leaving it with any person at the premises; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the identity of the immediate landlord is not known, a summons may be issued to him by reference to his status as such, without naming him.

subsection.content: On the hearing of an application under subsection (1), the court or magistrate may, if satisfied that a condition of the suspension order has been broken, make an order reviving the closure order.

subsection.leadIn: Where a court or magistrate makes an order under subsection (4) reviving a closure order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 153B applies with the necessary modifications;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court or magistrate shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, send a copy of the order made under subsection (4), sealed with the seal of the court or signed by the magistrate, to the Land Registrar; and (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the period during which the closure order was suspended shall not count as part of the period for which the closure order is in force.

section.name: s153L
section.heading: Applications under sections 153C, 153I, 153J and 153K
section.leadIn: An application under section 153C, 153I(1), 153J(1) or 153K(1) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the closure order was made by a magistrate, be made to a magistrate and, so far as is practicable, be made to the magistrate who made the order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the closure order was made by the District Court, be made to the District Court and, so far as is practicable, be made to the judge who made the order;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the closure order was made by the Court of First Instance, be made to the Court of First Instance and, so far as is practicable, be made to the judge who made the order. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s153M
section.heading: Registration of notices and orders relating to premises

subsection.leadIn: Where the Land Registrar receives a notice sent to him under section 145A, 153C(6) or 153H(4), or a copy of an order sent to him under section 153A(2), 153I(8) or 153K(5), he shall as soon as reasonably practicable,— (Amended 80 of 1997 s. 102)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prepare and verify a memorial of the notice or copy of an order, that memorial being in the form prescribed and containing the particulars required by or under the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: register the notice or copy of an order.

subsection.content: A notice or copy of an order required to be sent to the Land Registrar under the provisions referred to in subsection (1) shall be deemed to be an instrument affecting land, but a failure to register such a notice or copy of an order shall not, save as is provided in section 153C, affect its validity as against any person. (Amended 8 of 1993 s. 3)
A memorial prepared under subsection (1) shall be regarded as complying with the Land Registration Ordinance (Cap. 128).

section.name: s153N
section.heading: Registration of notices and orders relating to vessels
section.content: Where the Director of Marine receives a notice sent to him under section 145A or 153H(5) or a copy of an order sent to him under section 153D(2) and the notice or order relates to a vessel certificated in accordance with regulations made or deemed to have been made under the Merchant Shipping (Local Vessels) Ordinance (Cap. 548), he shall as soon as reasonably practicable register the notice or copy of an order in a register maintained by him.

section.name: s153O
section.heading: Obstruction

subsection.content: Any person who obstructs any person in the exercise of any function under section 153B(3) shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), any person who without lawful authority or reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: interferes with any lock, bar or other thing used to close any premises or place subject to a closure order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: enters or is in any premises or place that has been closed under a closure order,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not apply—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the closure order is no longer in force or is suspended under section 153I;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a public officer acting in the course of his duty;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to a person who has the permission in writing of a magistrate.

part.crossHeading:
Certain sexual offences committed against
children outside Hong Kong; related
arrangements and advertisements

section.name: s153P
section.heading: Extra-territorial effect of sexual offence provisions listed in Schedule 2

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a

subparagraph.content: a person who is a Hong Kong permanent resident or who ordinarily resides in Hong Kong;
a body corporate that is incorporated or registered in Hong Kong; or
a body of persons, whether corporate or unincorporate, that has a place of business in Hong Kong,

paragraph.continued: commits any act outside Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the act—

subparagraph.content: would have constituted an offence under any of the provisions specified in Schedule 2 had it been committed in Hong Kong; and
is committed in relation to a person under the age of 16 or, in the case of an offence under section 123 or 140, under the age of 13,

subsection.continued: then the person or body shall be guilty of that offence.

subsection.leadIn: Where any person or body of persons, whether corporate or unincorporate, commits any act outside Hong Kong that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: would have constituted an offence under any of the provisions specified in Schedule 2 had it been committed in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: is committed in relation to a person who is a Hong Kong permanent resident or who ordinarily resides in Hong Kong and is—

subparagraph.content: under the age of 16; or
in the case of an offence under section 123 or 140, under the age of 13,

subsection.continued: then the person or body shall be guilty of that offence.

subsection.leadIn: Where a defendant is charged with an offence that is an offence by virtue of subsection (1) or (2) and involves a sexual act done by him with or to another person, it is a defence for the defendant to establish that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: at the time of the sexual act, there existed between the defendant and that other person a marriage that was valid, or recognized as valid, under the law of—

subparagraph.content: the place where the marriage was solemnized;
the place where the sexual act was done; or
the place of the defendant’s residence or domicile;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: when it was solemnized, the marriage was genuine; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: at the time of the sexual act, that other person consented to the sexual act.

section.name: s153Q
section.heading: Arrangement or advertisement relating to commission against a child of act outside Hong Kong that offends Schedule 2 provision

subsection.content: Any person who makes arrangements, whether wholly or partly in Hong Kong, for himself or another person to commit any act in relation to a person under the age of 16 that would constitute an offence under any of the provisions specified in Schedule 2 if it were committed in Hong Kong, commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $3,000,000 and to imprisonment for 10 years.

Any person who publishes, distributes or publicly displays, or causes or permits the publication, distribution or public display of an advertisement for any arrangements referred to in subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine of $3,000,000 and to imprisonment for 10 years.

subsection.def: For the purposes of subsection (2), distribute (分發) includes making any message or data available through any means of electronic transmission.

subsection.content: It is a defence to a charge under subsection (2) for the defendant to establish that he had not seen the advertisement and did not know, nor did he have any reasonable cause to suspect, it to be an advertisement mentioned in that subsection.

section.name: s153R
section.heading: Amendment of Schedule 2
section.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, with the approval of the Legislative Council, amend Schedule 2 by order published in the Gazette.

part.crossHeading:
Restrictions on evidence and on publishing
details regarding identity

section.name: s154
section.heading: Restrictions on evidence at trials for rape etc.

subsection.content: If at a trial before the Court of First Instance any person is for the time being charged with a rape offence or indecent assault to which he pleads not guilty (whether or not at the trial he, or any other person, is for the time being charged with an offence which is not a rape offence or indecent assault), then, except with the leave of the judge, no evidence and no question in cross-examination shall be adduced or asked at the trial, by or on behalf of any defendant at the trial, about any sexual experience of a complainant with a person other than that defendant. (Amended 32 of 1979 s. 2; 25 of 1998 s. 2)

The judge shall not give leave in pursuance of subsection (1) for any evidence or question except on an application made to him in the absence of the jury by or on behalf of a defendant; and on such an application the judge shall give leave if and only if he is satisfied that it would be unfair to that defendant to refuse to allow the evidence to be adduced or the question to be asked.

subsection.def: In subsection (1) complainant (申訴人) means a woman upon whom, in a charge for a rape offence or indecent assault to which the trial in question relates, it is alleged that rape or indecent assault was committed, attempted or proposed. (Amended 32 of 1979 s. 2)

subsection.content: Nothing in this section authorizes evidence to be adduced or a question to be asked which cannot be adduced or asked apart from this section.

section.name: s155
section.heading: Application of s. 154 to committal proceedings, District Court and summary trials

subsection.content: Where, on a hearing under Part III of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227), a magistrate inquires into a rape offence or indecent assault, then, except with the consent of the magistrate, evidence shall not be adduced and a question shall not be asked at the hearing which, if the hearing were a trial at which a person is charged with a rape offence or indecent assault and each of the accused at the hearing were charged at the trial with the offences of which he is accused at the hearing, could not be adduced or asked without leave in pursuance of section 154. (Amended 32 of 1979 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: On an application for consent in pursuance of subsection (1) for any evidence or question the magistrate shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: refuse the consent unless he is satisfied that leave in respect of the evidence or question would be likely to be given at a relevant trial;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give the consent if he is so satisfied.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person charged with a rape offence or indecent assault is tried for that offence either in the District Court or summarily before a magistrate under Part V of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227) or in a juvenile court under the Juvenile Offenders Ordinance (Cap. 226) section 154 shall have effect in relation to the trial as if— (Amended 32 of 1979 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the words “in the absence of the jury” in subsection (2) thereof were omitted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for any reference to the judge there were substituted—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of a trial in the District Court, a reference to the District Judge before whom the trial takes place;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a trial before a magistrate, a reference to the magistrate;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a trial in a juvenile court, a reference to the juvenile court.

section.name: s156
section.heading: Anonymity of complainants

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (9)(a), after an allegation is made that a specified sexual offence has been committed no matter likely to lead members of the public to identify any person as the complainant in relation to that allegation shall either be published in Hong Kong in a written publication available to the public or be broadcast in Hong Kong except as authorized by a direction given in pursuance of this section.

subsection.leadIn: If, before the commencement of a trial at which a person is charged with a specified sexual offence, he or another person against whom the complainant may be expected to give evidence at the trial applies to a judge for a direction in pursuance of this subsection and satisfies the judge—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the direction is required for the purpose of inducing persons to come forward who are likely to be needed as witnesses at the trial; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the conduct of the applicant’s defence at the trial is likely to be substantially prejudiced if the direction is not given,

subsection.continued: the judge shall direct that subsection (1) shall not, by virtue of the accusation alleging the offence aforesaid, apply in relation to the complainant.

subsection.content: If after the commencement of a trial at which a person is charged with a specified sexual offence a new trial of the person for that offence is ordered, the commencement of any previous trial at which he was charged with that offence shall be disregarded for the purposes of subsection (2). [cf. 1976 c. 82 s. 5(2) U.K.]

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.leadIn: A direction that subsection (1) shall not apply in relation to such complaint or such matter as is specified in the direction may be given, where it is necessary for the purpose of seeking information which may lead to the arrest of a person responsible for an alleged specified sexual offence, or is for any other reason in the public interest—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a police officer of the rank of Senior Superintendent or above, where the complainant consents in writing to such a direction being given; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by the Secretary for Justice in any other case, (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

subsection.continued: and notice of any such direction shall be published in the Gazette. (Added 26 of 1980 s. 2)

subsection.content: If at a trial at which a person is charged with a specified sexual offence the judge or, as the case may be, the District Judge, magistrate or juvenile court, is satisfied that the effect of subsection (1) is to impose a substantial and unreasonable restriction upon the reporting of proceedings at the trial and that it is in the public interest to remove or relax the restriction, the judge or, as the case may be, the District Judge, magistrate or juvenile court, shall direct that subsection (1) shall not apply to such matter relating to the complainant as is specified in the direction; but a direction shall not be given in pursuance of this subsection by reason only of an acquittal of a defendant at the trial.

subsection.leadIn: If a person who has been convicted of an offence and given notice of an appeal to the Court of Appeal against the conviction, or notice of an application for leave so to appeal, applies to the Court of Appeal for a direction in pursuance of this subsection and satisfies the Court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the direction is required for the purpose of obtaining evidence in support of the appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the applicant is likely to suffer substantial injustice if the direction is not given,

subsection.continued: the Court shall direct that subsection (1) shall not, by virtue of such allegation of a specified sexual offence as is specified in the direction, apply in relation to a complainant so specified.

subsection.content: Subsection (5) shall apply in relation to a conviction of an offence tried summarily as mentioned in section 155(3), and, in so applying for references to the Court of Appeal there shall be substituted references to a judge and the reference to notice of an application for leave to appeal shall be omitted. [cf. 1976 c. 82 s. 5(3) U.K.]

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this section an allegation of a specified sexual offence is made if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is made to a police officer; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a complaint is made to or an information is laid before a magistrate alleging that a person has committed a specified sexual offence against the complainant; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person appears before a magistrate or a court charged with a specified sexual offence against the complainant; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person is committed for trial at the Court of First Instance on a charge alleging a specified sexual offence against the complainant; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: an indictment charging a person with a specified sexual offence against the complainant is preferred before the Court of First Instance,

subsection.continued: and references in this section to an allegation of a specified sexual offence shall be construed accordingly. (Replaced 26 of 1980 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: broadcast (廣播) means a broadcast by wireless telegraphy of sound or visual images intended for general reception;
complainant (申訴人), in relation to an allegation of a specified sexual offence, means the person against whom the offence is alleged to have been committed; and
written publication (書刊) includes a film, a sound track and any other record in permanent form but does not include an indictment or other document prepared for use in particular legal proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prohibits the publication or broadcasting, in consequence of an allegation of a specified sexual offence, of matter consisting only of a report of legal proceedings other than proceedings at, or intended to lead to, or on an appeal arising out of, a trial at which a person is charged with that offence; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: affects any prohibition or restriction imposed by virtue of any other enactment upon a publication or broadcast,

subsection.continued: and a direction in pursuance of this section does not affect the operation of subsection (1) at any time before the direction is given.

section.name: s157
section.heading: Offences and proceedings

subsection.leadIn: If any matter is published or broadcast in contravention of section 156(1), the following persons, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a publication in a newspaper or periodical, any proprietor, any editor and any publisher of the newspaper or periodical;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of any other publication, the person who publishes it; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a broadcast, any body corporate which transmits or provides the programme in which the broadcast is made and any person having functions in relation to the programme corresponding to those of an editor of a newspaper,

subsection.continued: shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2021)

subsection.content: When an offence under subsection (1) which has been committed by a body corporate is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate or any person who was purporting to act in any such capacity, he as well as the body corporate shall be guilty of that offence and be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

Where the affairs of a body corporate are managed by its members subsection (2) shall apply in relation to the acts and defaults of a member in connexion with his functions of management as if he were a director of the body corporate.

Proceedings for an offence under subsection (1) (including such an offence which is alleged to have been committed by virtue of subsection (2), whether or not by virtue also of subsection (3) ) shall not be instituted except by or with the consent of the Secretary for Justice; and where a person is charged with such an offence it shall be a defence to prove that at the time of the alleged offence he was not aware, and neither suspected nor had reason to suspect, that the publication or broadcast in question was of such matter as is mentioned in section 156(1). (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

section.name: s159
section.heading: Transitional provisions

subsection.content: Sections 154 and 155 shall not have effect in relation to a trial or inquiry which begins before the coming into operation of the Crimes (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 1978 (25 of 1978). (Added 25 of 1978 s. 4. Amended 32 of 1979 s. 4)

Sections 154 and 155 shall not have effect in relation to a trial or inquiry at which a person is charged with indecent assault which begins before the coming into operation of the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 1979 (32 of 1979). (Added 32 of 1979 s. 4)

part.name: P12AA
part.heading: Voyeurism, Unlawful Recording or Observation of Intimate Parts, Related Image Publication Offences and Disposal Order

section.name: s159AA
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: breasts (胸部) means the breasts of an individual regardless of the individual’s sex;
disregard (不理會), in relation to a consent, see section 159AAH;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a photograph, video recording or film; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a static or moving visual record;

def.name: IntimateImage
def.leadIn: intimate image (私密影像), in relation to an individual—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: means an image showing—

subparagraph.content: an intimate part of the individual; or
the individual doing an intimate act; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: includes an image that has been altered to appear to show—

subparagraph.content: an intimate part of the individual; or
the individual doing an intimate act,

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: does not include an image so altered that no reasonable person would believe that it shows—

subparagraph.content: an intimate part of the individual; or
the individual doing an intimate act;

def.name: IntimatePart
def.leadIn: intimate part (私密部位), in relation to an individual, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the individual’s genitals, buttocks, anal region or breasts (whether exposed or only covered with underwear); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the individual’s underwear covering genitals, buttocks, anal region or breasts;

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: means creating or generating an image; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: includes any act of making a visual record that is transmitted in real time with or without retention or storage in—

subparagraph.content: a physical form; or
an electronic form from which the record is capable of being reproduced with or without the aid of any device;

subsection.def: sexual purpose (性目的), in relation to a person, includes the stimulation or satisfaction of the sexual desire of the person or any other person;
structure (構築物) includes any aircraft, vehicle, vessel, tent and other temporary or movable structure.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part, an individual is doing an intimate act if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the individual is using the toilet in a manner that an intimate part of the individual is likely to be revealed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the individual is doing a sexual act that is not of a kind ordinarily done in public.

subsection.content: For the purposes of this Part, a person operates equipment even if the person merely enables or secures its activation by another person without that other person’s knowledge.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part, a person publishes an image if the person, whether or not for any form of reward—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: distributes, circulates, makes available, sells, hires, sends, gives or lends the image to another person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shows the image in any manner to or for another person (including showing, playing or projecting the image to or for another person using any machinery or apparatus and publicly displaying the image).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (4), a reference to distributing, circulating, making available or sending an image to a person includes a reference to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: making available to the person any data from which the image is capable of being reproduced; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making available to the person any hyperlink, or location on an electronic platform, that gives access to the image or any data from which the image is capable of being reproduced.

section.name: s159AAB
section.heading: Voyeurism

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person surreptitiously—

subparagraph.content: observes (with or without the aid of equipment) or records an individual in a place in which any individual can reasonably be expected to be nude, to reveal an intimate part, or to be doing an intimate act;

observes (with or without the aid of equipment) or records an intimate part of an individual, or an individual doing an intimate act, for the purpose of observing or recording an intimate part or an intimate act, of any individual; or
observes (with or without the aid of equipment) or records an individual for a sexual purpose;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the individual who is being observed or recorded as described in paragraph (a)(i), (ii) or (iii) (subject individual) is in circumstances that give rise to a reasonable expectation of privacy; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person disregards whether the subject individual consents to being observed or recorded by the person.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: installs or operates equipment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: constructs or adapts a structure or a part of a structure,

subsection.continued: for the purpose of enabling the person or any other person to commit an offence under subsection (1).

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

section.name: s159AAC
section.heading: Unlawful recording or observation of intimate parts

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the person—

subparagraph.content: records an intimate part of an individual, in circumstances in which the intimate part would not otherwise be visible; or

subparagraph.leadIn: with intent to observe or record an intimate part of an individual—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: operates equipment for the purpose of observing or recording an intimate part of the individual from beneath the clothing of the individual; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: operates equipment in an unreasonable manner for the purpose of observing or recording an intimate part of the individual through an opening or a gap in the outer clothing of the individual,

subparagraph.continued: in circumstances in which the intimate part would not otherwise be visible;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person engages in the conduct described in paragraph (a)(i) or (ii)—

subparagraph.content: for a sexual purpose; or
dishonestly; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person disregards whether the individual referred to in paragraph (a)(i) or (ii) consents to the person’s conduct described in that paragraph.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

section.name: s159AAD
section.heading: Publication of images originating from commission of offence under section 159AAB(1) or 159AAC(1)

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person publishes an image of an individual (subject individual);

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: the person—

subparagraph.content: knows that the image originates from the commission of a specified offence, or is reckless as to whether the image originates from the commission of a specified offence; and
disregards whether the subject individual consents to the publication.

subsection.content: For subsection (1)(b), it is immaterial whether the specified offence is committed by the person.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (1)(c)(i)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is taken to know a specified offence has been committed if the person is aware of all the matters that must be established in order to prove the specified offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person is taken to be reckless as to whether a specified offence has been committed if the person is reckless as to the existence of all those matters.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

section.name: s159AAE
section.heading: Publication or threatened publication of intimate images without consent

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person publishes an intimate image of an individual;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person—

subparagraph.content: intends the publication to cause humiliation, alarm or distress to the individual; or
knows or is reckless as to whether the publication will or is likely to cause humiliation, alarm or distress to the individual;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no consent is given by the individual to the publication; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the person disregards whether the individual consents to the publication.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person makes a threat to publish an intimate image of an individual;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person, when making the threat—

subparagraph.content: intends the threat to cause humiliation, alarm or distress to the individual; or
knows or is reckless as to whether the threat will or is likely to cause humiliation, alarm or distress to the individual;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no consent is given by the individual to the threatened publication; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the person disregards whether the individual consents to the threatened publication.

subsection.leadIn: For subsections (1) and (2), it is immaterial whether the intimate image is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: created, generated or obtained in Hong Kong or elsewhere;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: created, generated or obtained by—

subparagraph.content: the individual referred to in subsection (1) or (2), as the case may be (subject individual); or
the person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: created, generated or obtained with or without the consent of the subject individual;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: created, generated or obtained before, on or after the day on which the Crimes (Amendment) Ordinance 2021 (35 of 2021) comes into operation*; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: provided to the person by the subject individual.

subsection.content: For subsection (2), it is immaterial whether the person is capable of publishing the intimate image.
A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

section.name: s159AAF
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: subject individual (事主) means an individual whose intimate act, intimate part or intimate image is the subject of a person’s conduct.

section.name: s159AAG
section.heading: Who cannot give consent that would prevent conduct from becoming offence under Division 2
section.leadIn: A subject individual cannot give a consent that would prevent a person’s conduct from becoming an offence under Division 2 if, at the time when the conduct takes place, the subject individual—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is under the age of 16; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a mentally incapacitated person as defined by section 117(1).

section.name: s159AAH
section.heading: Disregard whether consent is given
section.leadIn: For the purposes of Division 2, a person disregards whether a subject individual consents to the person’s conduct if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: knows that the subject individual does not consent to the conduct; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is reckless as to whether the subject individual consents to the conduct.

section.name: s159AAI
section.heading: Defence regarding age or mental capacity of subject individual

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to proceedings against a person charged with an offence under Division 2 if the subject individual—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is under the age of 16; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is a mentally incapacitated person as defined by section 117(1).

subsection.leadIn: It is a defence for the person to prove that the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: honestly believed that a consent was given by the subject individual to the person’s conduct that would constitute the offence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: did not know and had no reason to suspect that the subject individual was an individual falling within subsection (1)(a) or (b).

subsection.content: The burden of proving a defence under subsection (2) lies on the person.

section.name: s159AAJ
section.heading: Defence regarding lawful authority or reasonable excuse

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), it is a defence for a person charged with an offence under Division 2 to establish that the person had lawful authority or reasonable excuse for the contravention.

subsection.leadIn: A person is taken to have established that the person had lawful authority or reasonable excuse referred to in subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to the lawful authority or reasonable excuse; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person charged with an offence under section 159AAB(1) that relates to section 159AAB(1)(a)(iii);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person charged with an offence under section 159AAB(2) that relates to section 159AAB(1)(a)(iii); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person charged with an offence under section 159AAC(1) in respect of the conduct described in section 159AAC(1)(a)(i) or (ii) that was engaged in by the person for a sexual purpose.

section.name: s159AAK
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: concerned person (相關人士), in relation to a disposal order, means a person described in section 159AAM(3)(a) or (b);

def.name: CriminalProceedings
def.leadIn: criminal proceedings (刑事法律程序), in relation to a specified offence—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: means proceedings, before any court or magistrate, in which a person is charged with the specified offence; and

paragraph.name: b

section.def: disposal order (處置令) means an order made under section 159AAL(1);
Magistrates Ordinance (《裁判官條例》) means the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227);
specified offence (指明罪行) means an offence, or an alleged offence, under section 159AAD or 159AAE;
subject person (處置令對象), in relation to a disposal order, means a person described in section 159AAM(2);
summons (傳票) means a summons issued under section 159AAM(2).

section.name: s159AAL
section.heading: Disposal order

subsection.content: A magistrate may, on application made in the name of the Secretary for Justice at any time during any criminal proceedings in relation to a specified offence concerning an image and subject to subsections (3) and (4) and section 159AAM, order a person, whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere, to take reasonable steps to remove, delete or destroy, or to cause the removal, deletion or destruction of, the image within a period to be specified by the magistrate.

A magistrate may still deal with an application under subsection (1) and make the disposal order even if the criminal proceedings to which the application relates do not take place before a magistrate.

subsection.leadIn: In an application made under subsection (1) for a disposal order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to an image proposed to be made subject to the disposal order—

subparagraph.content: the image must be identified;
it must be proved that the image is an intimate image of an individual; and
it must be proved that the image is a subject of the criminal proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to a person proposed to be made subject to the disposal order—

subparagraph.content: the person must be identified by stating the person’s particulars;
it must be proved that the person has the means to control, or is in possession, of an image; and
it must be proved that the person is able to take the actions required under the terms proposed in the application to be specified in the disposal order.

subsection.content: A magistrate must not make a disposal order against a person in relation to an image unless the magistrate is satisfied that all matters that are required to be proved for the purposes of the application have been proved on a balance of probabilities.

subsection.leadIn: After a disposal order is made, a magistrate may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the magistrate’s own motion;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on application made in the name of the Secretary for Justice; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: on application by the subject person, or a concerned person,

subsection.continued: review the disposal order, and affirm, suspend, vary, cancel or revoke the disposal order as the magistrate considers appropriate.

subsection.content: Subject to section 159AAM, a magistrate may determine an application under subsection (1) or review a disposal order under subsection (5) based on written materials without calling any witness.
The Secretary for Justice may appoint a person or class of persons to make an application under subsection (1) or (5)(b).

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the validity of a disposal order is not affected only by—

subparagraph.content: the verdict of acquittal or quashing of a conviction on appeal, of the specified offence to which the disposal order relates;
proceedings under section 104 of the Magistrates Ordinance, in relation to the specified offence;
the discontinuation of the prosecution of the specified offence; or
the termination of the criminal proceedings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the time limit of 14 clear days under section 104 of the Magistrates Ordinance does not apply in relation to a magistrate’s power to review a disposal order under subsection (5).

section.name: s159AAM
section.heading: Procedures in relation to disposal order

subsection.leadIn: An application under section 159AAL(1) or (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be made in writing; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be filed with a magistrate.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (4), before making a disposal order against a person in relation to an image, or reviewing a disposal order made against a person in relation to an image, a magistrate must issue a summons to the person to appear on the day specified in the summons to make representations.

subsection.leadIn: If a person, other than the subject person, claims that the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has an interest in an image that is, or is proposed to be, made subject to a disposal order; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would be directly affected by the making or review of the disposal order,

subsection.continued: the person may also appear on the day specified in the summons to make representations.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the subject person named in the summons cannot for any reason be found;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the subject person named in the summons has refused to accept the service of the summons; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the summons has been served on the subject person named in the summons but that person has not attended the hearing on the day specified in the summons,

subsection.continued: the magistrate may still make or review the disposal order based on written materials without calling any witness and without a hearing.

section.name: s159AAN
section.heading: Service of summons and disposal order

subsection.content: The service of a summons or disposal order in Hong Kong is to be made by a police officer.
A summons must be served together with a copy of the application to which the summons relates.

subsection.leadIn: A summons or disposal order is to be regarded as having been duly served in Hong Kong on a person if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is served by hand on the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is left at the person’s last known address; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: it is sent by registered post addressed to the person at the person’s last known address.

subsection.content: The service of a summons or disposal order out of the jurisdiction is permissible with the leave of a magistrate.

The service of a summons or disposal order out of the jurisdiction is effected if the summons or disposal order is served on the person in accordance with the law of the jurisdiction in which the service is effected.

If a magistrate grants leave to serve a summons or disposal order out of the jurisdiction, the magistrate may give directions in relation to the service, having regard to the procedures set out in Order 11, rule 5A or 6 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A), as if the procedures were applicable, with necessary modifications, to the service.
If the service of a summons or disposal order has been effected, the proof of service must be filed with a magistrate.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: ProofOfService
def.leadIn: proof of service (送達證明), in relation to service of any summons or disposal order, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for service in Hong Kong—statutory declaration as to the service made by the police officer who effected the service; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for service out of the jurisdiction—applicable proof of service in accordance with the applicable law of the jurisdiction in which the service is effected.

section.name: s159AAO
section.heading: Offence relating to disposal order

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has been made subject to a disposal order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has been served with the disposal order; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fails to comply with the disposal order.

subsection.content: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on conviction on indictment to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 1 year.
It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (1) to establish that the person had a reasonable excuse for not complying with the disposal order.

subsection.leadIn: The person is taken to have established that the person had reasonable excuse referred to in subsection (3) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: there is sufficient evidence to raise an issue with respect to the reasonable excuse; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s159A
section.heading: The offence of conspiracy

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the following provisions of this Part, if a person agrees with any other person or persons that a course of conduct shall be pursued which, if the agreement is carried out in accordance with their intentions, either—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: will necessarily amount to or involve the commission of any offence or offences by one or more of the parties to the agreement; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: would do so but for the existence of facts which render the commission of the offence or any of the offences impossible,

subsection.continued: he is guilty of conspiracy to commit the offence or offences in question.

subsection.content: Where liability for any offence may be incurred without knowledge on the part of the person committing it of any particular fact or circumstance necessary for the commission of the offence, a person shall nevertheless not be guilty of conspiracy to commit that offence by virtue of subsection (1) unless he and at least one other party to the agreement intend or know that that fact or circumstance shall or will exist at the time when the conduct constituting the offence is to take place.

subsection.def: In this section offence (罪行) means any offence triable in Hong Kong and includes murder notwithstanding that the murder in question would not be so triable if committed in accordance with the intentions of the parties to the agreement. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2017)

section.name: s159B
section.heading: Exemptions from liability for conspiracy

subsection.content: A person shall not by virtue of section 159A be guilty of conspiracy to commit any offence if he is an intended victim of that offence.

subsection.leadIn: A person shall not by virtue of section 159A be guilty of conspiracy to commit any offence or offences if the only other person or persons with whom he agrees are (both initially and at all times during the currency of the agreement) persons of any one or more of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: his spouse;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person under the age of criminal responsibility; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an intended victim of that offence or of each of those offences.

subsection.content: A person is under the age of criminal responsibility for the purposes of subsection (2)(b) so long as it is conclusively presumed, by virtue of section 3 of the Juvenile Offenders Ordinance (Cap. 226), that he cannot be guilty of any offence.

section.name: s159C
section.heading: Penalties

subsection.leadIn: A person guilty of conspiracy to commit any offence or offences by virtue of section 159A shall be liable on conviction on indictment—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in a case falling within subsection (3) or (4), to imprisonment for a term related in accordance with that subsection to the gravity of the offence or offences in question (referred to in this section as the relevant offence or offences); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, to a fine.

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(b) shall not be taken as prejudicing the application of section 113A of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) (power of court to fine) in a case falling within subsection (3) or (4).

subsection.leadIn: Where the relevant offence or any of the relevant offences is an offence of any of the following descriptions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: murder, or any other offence the sentence for which is mandatory life imprisonment; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an offence for which a sentence extending to imprisonment for life is provided,

subsection.continued: the person convicted shall be liable to imprisonment for life.

subsection.content: Where in a case other than one to which subsection (3) applies the relevant offence or any of the relevant offences is punishable with imprisonment, the person convicted shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding the maximum term provided for that offence or (where more than one such offence is in question) for any one of those offences (taking the longer or the longest term as the limit for the purposes of this section where the terms provided differ).

A person guilty of conspiracy to commit any offence or offences by virtue of section 159A shall, where the relevant offence or any of the relevant offences is triable on indictment or summarily, be liable on summary conviction to any penalty to which he would have been liable on summary conviction of that relevant offence or any of the relevant offences.
A person convicted of the offence at common law of conspiracy to defraud shall be liable to imprisonment for 14 years.

Where any Ordinance confers a power of imposing pecuniary penalties or of forfeiture, seizure and search, or any powers and discretions to cancel, suspend or refuse to issue any licence, permit or other authorization, or imposes a duty which is to be exercised or performed consequent upon a conviction of a relevant offence or in relation to a person who is detained in custody for a relevant offence, then that power or duty shall be deemed to be also exercisable or performable consequent upon a conviction of a conspiracy to commit that relevant offence, but nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to authorize the imposition of any sentence of imprisonment otherwise than in default of payment of any pecuniary penalty which may be imposed by virtue of this subsection.

section.name: s159D
section.heading: Restriction on the institution of proceedings

subsection.leadIn: Where— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 38)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence has been committed in pursuance of any agreement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: proceedings may not be instituted for that offence because any time limit applicable to the institution of any such proceedings has expired,

subsection.continued: proceedings under section 159A for conspiracy to commit that offence shall not be instituted against any person on the basis of that agreement.

subsection.content: Any prohibition imposed by any enactment on the institution of proceedings for any offence otherwise than by, or on behalf or with the consent of, the Secretary for Justice or any other person also applies in relation to proceedings instituted under section 159A for conspiracy to commit that offence. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 38)

section.name: s159E
section.heading: Abolitions, savings and transitional provisions

subsection.content: Subject to the following provisions of this section, the offence of conspiracy at common law is abolished.
Subsection (1) shall not affect the offence of conspiracy at common law so far as relates to conspiracy to defraud.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person agrees with any other person or persons that a course of conduct shall be pursued; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that course of conduct will necessarily amount to or involve the commission of any offence or offences by one or more of the parties to the agreement if the agreement is carried out in accordance with their intentions,

subsection.continued: the fact that it will do so shall not preclude a charge of conspiracy to defraud being brought against any of them in respect of the agreement.

subsection.content: A person shall not be entitled to be acquitted of, or to have quashed his conviction for, the offence of conspiracy for the reason only that the only other person or persons with whom he is alleged, in the indictment or charge sheet, to have entered into that conspiracy are or have been acquitted.
Any rule of law or practice inconsistent with the provisions of subsection (4) is abolished.

The rules laid down by sections 159A and 159B shall apply for determining whether a person is guilty of an offence of conspiracy under any enactment other than section 159A, but conduct which is an offence under any such other enactment shall not also be an offence under section 159A.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) shall not affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings commenced before the time when this Part comes into operation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any proceedings commenced after that time against a person charged with the same conspiracy as that charged in any proceedings commenced before that time.

section.name: s159F
section.heading: Application
section.content: Sections 159A to 159E shall apply to an agreement which falls within section 6 of the Criminal Jurisdiction Ordinance (Cap. 461).

section.name: s159G
section.heading: Attempting to commit an offence

subsection.content: A person who, intending to commit an offence to which this section applies, does an act that is more than merely preparatory to the commission of the offence is guilty of attempting to commit the offence.
A person may be guilty of attempting to commit an offence to which this section applies even though the facts are such that the commission of the offence is impossible.
Where a person is charged with an offence, he may be convicted of having attempted to commit that offence even though he was not charged with the attempt.

subsection.leadIn: In any case where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: apart from this subsection a person’s intention would not be regarded as having amounted to an intent to commit an offence; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facts of the case had been as he believed them to be, his intention would be so regarded,

subsection.continued: then, for the purposes of subsection (1), he shall be regarded as having had an intent to commit that offence.

subsection.content: This section applies to any offence which, if it were completed, would be triable in Hong Kong other than aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the commission of an offence.

section.name: s159H
section.heading: Application of procedural and other provisions to offences under section 159G

subsection.content: Any provision to which this section applies shall have effect with respect to an offence under section 159G of attempting to commit an offence as it has effect with respect to the offence attempted.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to provisions of any of the following descriptions made by or under any enactment (whenever passed)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provisions whereby proceedings may not be instituted or carried on otherwise than by, or on behalf or with the consent of, any person (including any provision which also makes other exceptions to the prohibition);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provisions conferring power to institute proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provisions as to the venue of proceedings;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: provisions whereby proceedings may not be instituted after the expiration of a time limit;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: provisions conferring a power to arrest or search;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: provisions conferring a power to seize and detain property;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: provisions conferring a power to impose pecuniary penalties;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: provisions conferring a power to forfeit, including any power to deal with anything liable to be forfeited;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: provisions conferring any powers and giving any discretions to cancel, suspend or refuse to issue any licence, permit or other authorization;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: provisions imposing a duty;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: provisions whereby a person may not be convicted or committed for trial on the uncorroborated evidence of one witness (including any provision requiring the evidence of not less than 2 credible witnesses);

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: provisions whereby, if an offence committed by a body corporate is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of another person, that person also is guilty of the offence.

section.name: s159I
section.heading: Offences of attempt under other enactments

subsection.content: Subsections (2) to (5) shall have effect, subject to subsection (6) and to any inconsistent provision in any other enactment, for the purpose of determining whether a person is guilty of an attempt under a special statutory provision.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance an attempt under a special statutory provision is an offence which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is created by an enactment other than section 159G, including an enactment passed after this Part; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is expressed as an offence of attempting to commit another offence (in this section referred to as the relevant full offence).

subsection.content: A person is guilty of an attempt under a special statutory provision if, with intent to commit the relevant full offence, he does an act which is more than merely preparatory to the commission of that offence.
A person may be guilty of an attempt under a special statutory provision even though the facts are such that the commission of the relevant full offence is impossible.

subsection.leadIn: In any case where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: apart from this subsection a person’s intention would not be regarded as having amounted to an intent to commit the relevant full offence; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the facts of the case had been as he believed them to be, his intention would be so regarded,

subsection.continued: then, for the purposes of subsection (3), he shall be regarded as having had an intent to commit that offence.

subsection.content: Subsections (2) to (5) shall not have effect in relation to an act done before the commencement of this Part.

section.name: s159J
section.heading: Trial and penalties

subsection.leadIn: A person guilty by virtue of section 159G of attempting to commit an offence shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the offence attempted is murder or any other offence the sentence for which is mandatory life imprisonment, be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for life;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the offence attempted is indictable but does not fall within paragraph (a), be liable on conviction on indictment to any penalty to which he would have been liable on conviction on indictment of that offence; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the offence attempted is triable on indictment or summarily, be liable on summary conviction to any penalty to which he would have been liable on summary conviction of that offence.

subsection.content: Where, in proceedings against a person for an offence under section 159G, there is evidence sufficient in law to support a finding that he did an act falling within subsection (1) of that section, the question whether or not his act fell within that subsection is a question of fact.

Where, in proceedings against a person for an attempt under a special statutory provision, there is evidence sufficient in law to support a finding that he did an act falling within section 159I(3), the question whether or not his act fell within that subsection is a question of fact.

Any power conferred, discretion given, or duty imposed by virtue of section 159H(2)(e), (f), (g), (h), (i) or (j) which is to be exercised or performed consequent upon a conviction of an offence or in relation to a person who is detained in custody for an offence, then that power, discretion or duty shall be deemed to be also exercisable or performable consequent upon a conviction of an attempt to commit that offence, but nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to authorize the imposition of any sentence of imprisonment otherwise than in default of payment of any pecuniary penalty which may be imposed by virtue of this subsection.

section.name: s159K
section.heading: Effect on common law

subsection.content: The offence of attempt at common law is abolished for all purposes not relating to acts done before the commencement of this Part.

Except as regards offences committed before the commencement of this Part, references in any enactment passed before this Part which fall to be construed as references to the offence of attempt at common law shall be construed as references to the offence under section 159G.

section.name: s159L
section.heading: Non-exclusivity of preliminary offences
section.content: Conviction of an offence under this Part or under another Ordinance is not precluded by the fact that the conduct in question constitutes an offence both under this Part and under that other Ordinance.

section.name: s160
section.heading: Loitering

subsection.content: A person who loiters in a public place or in the common parts of any building with intent to commit an arrestable offence commits an offence and is liable to a fine at level 3 and to imprisonment for 6 months. (Replaced 74 of 1992 s. 3. Amended E.R. 4 of 2021)

Any person who loiters in a public place or in the common parts of any building and in any way wilfully obstructs any person using that place or the common parts of that building, shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to imprisonment for 6 months.

If any person loiters in a public place or in the common parts of any building and his presence there, either alone or with others, causes any person reasonably to be concerned for his safety or well-being, he shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to imprisonment for 2 years.

def.name: CommonParts
def.leadIn: In this section common parts (共用部分), in relation to a building, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any entrance hall, lobby, passageway, corridor, staircase, landing, rooftop, lift or escalator;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any cellar, toilet, water closet, wash house, bath-house or kitchen which is in common use by the occupiers of the building;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any compound, garage, carpark, car port or lane.

section.name: s161
section.heading: Access to computer with criminal or dishonest intent

subsection.leadIn: Any person who obtains access to a computer—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with intent to commit an offence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with a dishonest intent to deceive;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: with a view to dishonest gain for himself or another; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: with a dishonest intent to cause loss to another,

subsection.continued: whether on the same occasion as he obtains such access or on any future occasion, commits an offence and is liable on conviction upon indictment to imprisonment for 5 years.

def.name: Gain,Loss
def.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1) gain (獲益) and loss (損失) are to be construed as extending not only to gain or loss in money or other property, but as extending to any such gain or loss whether temporary or permanent; and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: gain (獲益) includes a gain by keeping what one has, as well as a gain by getting what one has not; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: loss (損失) includes a loss by not getting what one might get, as well as a loss by parting with what one has.
